WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name MRS C.T. MERRIARTY
Address TIGHEFIELD, SASK.
Birthplace WIERKHOVEN, NETHERLAND.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? Acreage, July 26, 1906, Tichenfield.
Where had you been living before that? VAASEN, PROV. GEERENLAND, NETHERLAND.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6 generally.
How far was it to your nearest store? 7 miles to Davidson via Yellowberry.
How often could a visit be made to the store? About twice a year (except early spring).
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Convegables.
Flour, coffee, tea, salt, syrup, rolled oats, corn meal, sugar, beans (dried), split peas, yeast cakes, salt pork.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? LAKE OF THE WOODS
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb bags.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.25.
How much did you use graham flour? About half for bread making.
Whole wheat flour? None used there yet.
Was flour milled locally? Yes, but not far away? 20 miles that year! 1908.
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 6 cents approx.
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes... Whole wheat? Farina? Yes...
Other? Wheat and barley.
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Not until later.
How did you grind it? With a stock feed chopper after cleaning it thoroughly.

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? Mostly 20 lb. bags.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.50.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Edwardsburg Crown Syrup.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 20 lb. tins.

At what price? $1.50.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From a cow in the usual way after we acquired one.

Butter? Same source.

Eggs? From chickens, some wild duck eggs.

What was the price of butter? 10 cents a lb. or eggs? 15 cents a dozen.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, but not here.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Edam cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Rabbits (wild).

Wild ducks, a quarter frozen beef for winter.

How did you get fresh meat? As above.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? Only by freezing in winter.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not till later.

If so what year was it organized? 1938.

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Wild game around.

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? No fish till later about 1930.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh, frozen.

Kinds? White fish, Jack fish, Tullibee.

6. Beverages

Red Rose
What kind of tea did you buy? Department Store
At what price? 35 cents a pound.
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Green beans, wasted ourselves.
Price? Heated coffee. What other beverages were used? Coffee, sometimes.
Milk and water.

7. Vegetables and Dried Fruits

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
50 cents a bushel.
Could you get potatoes at the store? Never tried.
If not, where from? Farm.
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: 1908.
Potatoes 1908. Cabbage 1908. Carrots 1908. Onions 1908.
Turnips 1908. Beets 1908.
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? A bushel and a peck.
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? In bulk.
What weight? 12 lbs.
How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Both bulk and boxes.
What was the price of prunes? 12 cents a pound.
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?
A few apples, raisins and currents, about 1910.

8. Preservation

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.
Peas? Yes.
Corn? String beans? Yes.
Saskatoons? Yes.
Other foods? Kale.
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1912.
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1912.
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1912.
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.
We also preserved string beans, onion and corn in salt hope crocks.
To what extent? Nearly surplus to prevent wastage.
Did you make your own vinegar? Yes, in the early years.
6. **Beverages**

   - Red Ross **Water** (at what price?) $3.50 for a pound.
   - What kind of tea did you buy? **Napoleon**. (Does or crown) green beans, black beans, etc.

7. **Vegetables**

   - What was the price of potatoes per bushel then you got them?
   - Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes, **Green Bread**.
   - If not, where from? **Farm**.
   - What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of? 1908.
   - Potatoes **1912**. Cabbage **1912**. Carrots **1912**.
   - Turnips **1912**. Beets **1912**.
   - In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? **A half bushel and a peck**.
   - How did you buy pumpkins, (in bulk or by the box)? **By the box**.
   - That weight? **10 lbs**.
   - How did the grocer handle pumpkins (or other)? **Half bushel boxes**.
   - Short was the time of harvest? **12 lbs. a pound**.
   - What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peach, bananas, raisins, currents or others)?
   - A few apples, raising and current, about 1910.

8. **Preserving**

   - In the early years did you preserve any foods by freezing?
   - Other foods? **Kale**.
   - What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? **1912**.
   - What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? **1912**.
   - What year did you first preserve meat by canning? **1912**.
   - Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? **Yes**.
   - To what extent? **Mainly**.
   - Did you make your own vinegar? **Yes**.

   We also preserved **many beans, lentils, and peas** in old grapevines.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (five dates where possible).

Our first grocery order from Eaton Winnipeg came mostly in strong tin containers. For instance tea, coffee, rice, laundry starch etc. etc. Now all this comes in cardboard and paper. Dried fruit came in wooden boxes now also in cardboard. Lard etc in tins pails now in cardboard.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g. winter or summer.

Breakfast: Rolled oats porridge. 1906.
Bread and butter or syrup. Father 49
Milk or coffee. Mother 45
Dinner: Potatoes, vegetables. Daughter 14
Meat if there was any. Son 12
Milk pudding desert.
Supper: Fried potatoes
Bread, butter and cheese.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Coming as we did from Holland, Xmas to us is a Religious Festival and no eating feast. So we did not have a special Xmas dinner till way later after having acquired the Canadian custom, and the wherewithal to make a dinner with.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Yes, we were, but through no fault of the country. In the winter of 1906-1907 we ran completely out of "grub." We did have provisions till the first of March, but this being a specially severe winter it lasted much longer. What happened then and how we got through, is another tale; The main thing is we're here to tell the tale.
Our first heavy order from Cabin Womper came mostly in strong tin containers. For milk and tea, coffee, etc., chunky stitch etc. Now all this comes in cardboard and paper. Dried fruit came in tins also, now also in cardboard. Land etc. in tin packs now in cardboard.

Breakfast: Rolled oats porridge.
- Bread and butter or syrup.
- Milk or coffee.

Dinner: Potatoes, vegetables.
- Meat if there was any.
- Milk pudding dessert.
- Bread, fruit, butter and cheese.

Coming as we did from Holland, Xmas to us a Religious Festival and no eating feast. So we did not have a special Xmas dinner till way later after having acquired the Canadian custom, and the no-time-with-thal to make a dinner with.

Yes, we were, but through no fault of the country.

In the winter of 1906 - 1907 we ran completely out of grub. We did have provisions till the first of March but this being a specially severe winter it lasted much longer. What happened then and how we got through is another tale. The main thing is we're here to tell the tale.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There is not any outstanding difference in preparation, that I can see, only we cook a little more elaborate, you might call it. And of course the pressure cookers and the new aluminum utensils make it slightly different.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Living as we do, on a farm, I cannot say that we rely on purchased or prepared food, only that we have some of it on our shelves to either round out our home-grown stuff, or to use in case of emergency like "sudden" visitors or such.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Looking at the above question, I'm afraid that you have but a hazy idea of the situation in the early years. Even when the town of Outlook was built in 1907, I believe, the only way to buy groceries was for us to take butter and eggs in there (20 miles) and trade in the store for staple groceries. It was not so much a question of what you wanted as to make that do, what you could get for your produce. Afterwards when the railroad connected us with Saskatoon, and we started to ship cream to the creameries there, we could buy a little better. Also by that time the grocer's shelves were a little better stocked.
There is not any outstanding difference in the preparation of meals in the 
winter. I have no regretted with them.
